repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
This is an attempt at testing something - I'd be interested in feedback on the general idea, but the way I've implemented is a fairly messy hack (and I'm aware of this...). If we actually want to follow this up then it probably needs a rewrite.

My belief is that the size of the module init function is often slowing down the C compiler because it's simply too big for it to keep track of. This change generates a separate C function per stat, and the module init function just calls them in sequence.

On my laptop it seemed to knock about 15% from the compilation-time of ExprNodes.py. But it's a fairly old laptop and there's probably a lot of thermal throttling involved. Therefore I'd like to see on the CI (I'm particularly interested in the `-all` tests, which are constantly pumping up against the 30 minute limit)

commit.message: Try splitting module init up into tiny bits
Fix issue with cpdef funcs hopefully

Attempt to split module init function

into many small functions to make it easier for the C compiler
and hopefully split it up

Fixed issue with merged in code

It seems to corrupt the func-state for reasons I don't quite
get

title: Split up module init function
